_**Hell on Wheels**_ is an American [Western](/wiki/Western_\(genre\) "Western
\(genre\)") [television series](/wiki/Television_program "Television program")
about the construction of the [First Transcontinental
Railroad](/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad "First Transcontinental
Railroad") across the United States. The series, which featured [Anson
Mount](/wiki/Anson_Mount "Anson Mount"), [Colm Meaney](/wiki/Colm_Meaney "Colm
Meaney"), [Common](/wiki/Common_\(rapper\) "Common \(rapper\)"), and
[Dominique McElligott](/wiki/Dominique_McElligott "Dominique McElligott"),
chronicled the [Union Pacific Railroad](/wiki/Union_Pacific_Railroad "Union
Pacific Railroad") and its laborers, mercenaries, prostitutes, surveyors, and
others who lived, worked, and died in the mobile encampment, called "[Hell on
Wheels](/wiki/Hell_on_Wheels "Hell on Wheels")", that followed the
[railhead](/wiki/Railhead "Railhead") west across the [Great
Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains"). In particular, the story focused
on Cullen Bohannon (Mount), a former [Confederate
soldier](/wiki/Confederate_States_Army "Confederate States Army") who, while
working as foreman and chief engineer on the railroad, initially attempted to
track down the [Union soldiers](/wiki/Union_Army "Union Army") who murdered
his wife and young son during the [American Civil
War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War"). The series, which
broadcast in the United States and Canada on the cable channel
[AMC](/wiki/AMC_\(TV_channel\) "AMC \(TV channel\)"), aired from November 6,
2011[2] to July 23, 2016.

The series was created and produced by [Joe](/wiki/Tony_Gayton "Tony Gayton")
and [Tony Gayton](/wiki/Tony_Gayton "Tony Gayton"), and developed by [Endemol
USA](/wiki/Endemol "Endemol"), under the stewardship of senior vice-president
of scripted programming Jeremy Gold, and it is produced by [Entertainment
One](/wiki/Entertainment_One "Entertainment One") and Nomadic Pictures.[2] In
2012, AMC announced creators Joe and Tony Gayton were no longer involved in
the day-to-day production of the series.[3] On December 12, 2012, AMC
announced that writer [John Wirth](/wiki/John_Wirth_\(television_producer\)
"John Wirth \(television producer\)") would take over as
[showrunner](/wiki/Showrunner "Showrunner") for the third season.

Season one (2011–12) began in 1865, shortly after the [assassination of
Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln "Assassination of
Abraham Lincoln"), season two (2012) covered 1866, seasons three (2013) and
four (2014) opened in 1867, season five (2015–16) carries the series into
1869. On November 7, 2014, _Hell on Wheels_ was renewed for a fifth and final
season comprising 14 episodes, split between 2015 and 2016.[4]

### Main
cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Main cast")]

  * [Anson Mount](/wiki/Anson_Mount "Anson Mount") as Cullen Bohannon, a former Confederate soldier who initially is determined to avenge the deaths of his wife Mary, and his son. However, Bohannon later leaves revenge in the past and devotes himself to the [Union Pacific Railroad](/wiki/Union_Pacific_Railroad "Union Pacific Railroad") during its westward expansion.
  * [Colm Meaney](/wiki/Colm_Meaney "Colm Meaney") as [Thomas "Doc" Durant](/wiki/Thomas_C._Durant "Thomas C. Durant"), a businessman and investor in the First Transcontinental Railroad, where he hopes to make his fortune.
  * [Common](/wiki/Common_\(rapper\) "Common \(rapper\)") as Elam Ferguson, a recently freed [slave](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States") who is trying to find his place in the world. He works as security and general assistant to Bohannon.
  * [Dominique McElligott](/wiki/Dominique_McElligott "Dominique McElligott") as Lily Bell, a recent widow; her husband was a surveyor working on the transcontinental rail project.
  * [Tom Noonan](/wiki/Tom_Noonan "Tom Noonan") as Reverend Nathaniel Cole, a minister who formerly participated in [Bleeding Kansas](/wiki/Bleeding_Kansas "Bleeding Kansas") prior to the Civil War; he is sick of the slaughter and wants to help the whites and Indians avoid another war.
  * [Eddie Spears](/wiki/Eddie_Spears "Eddie Spears") as Joseph Black Moon, a [Cheyenne](/wiki/Cheyenne_people "Cheyenne people") who must choose between the new world and the traditions of his ancestors.
  * [Ben Esler](/wiki/Ben_Esler "Ben Esler") as Seán McGinnes, an ambitious young Irishman looking to make his fortune in the West.
  * [Phil Burke](/wiki/Phil_Burke "Phil Burke") as Mickey McGinnes, Sean's brother, who has travelled with Seán to America.
  * [Christopher Heyerdahl](/wiki/Christopher_Heyerdahl "Christopher Heyerdahl") as Thor Gundersen, Durant's head of security. He is known as "The Swede", even though he is [Norwegian](/wiki/Norwegians "Norwegians").
  * [Robin McLeavy](/wiki/Robin_McLeavy "Robin McLeavy") as Eva, a woman with a prominent chin-tattoo given to her while in the captivity of Indians. She initially supports herself by working in the Hell on Wheels brothel.
  * [Kasha Kropinski](/wiki/Kasha_Kropinski "Kasha Kropinski") as Ruth Cole, Reverend Cole's abandoned daughter and the heir to his church.
  * [Dohn Norwood](/wiki/Dohn_Norwood "Dohn Norwood") as Psalms Jackson, a freed former slave and criminal, whose prison sentence has been purchased by the railroad.
  * [Jennifer Ferrin](/wiki/Jennifer_Ferrin "Jennifer Ferrin") as Louise Ellison, a smart, witty, and flirtatious journalist hired by the _New York Tribune_ to cover the "story of the century".
  * [MacKenzie Porter](/wiki/MacKenzie_Porter "MacKenzie Porter") as Naomi Hatch, Aaron Hatch's daughter and Cullen's second wife. 
    * [Siobhan Williams](/wiki/Siobhan_Williams "Siobhan Williams") portrayed Naomi in a recurring role in the third season.
  * [Jake Weber](/wiki/Jake_Weber "Jake Weber") as [John Allen Campbell](/wiki/John_Allen_Campbell "John Allen Campbell"), Wyoming's first governor.
  * [Tim Guinee](/wiki/Tim_Guinee "Tim Guinee") as [Collis Huntington](/wiki/Collis_Huntington "Collis Huntington"), investor in the Central Pacific Railroad
  * [Byron Mann](/wiki/Byron_Mann "Byron Mann") as Chang, supplier for the Chinese workers for not only shops but also the opium dens and brothels.
  * [Reg Rogers](/wiki/Reg_Rogers "Reg Rogers") as James Strobridge, a worker for the Central Pacific Railroad.
  * Angela Zhou as Mei/Fong, a Chinese railroad worker for the Central Pacific Railroad.
  * [Chelah Horsdal](/wiki/Chelah_Horsdal "Chelah Horsdal") as Maggie Palmer, a prominent businesswoman in Cheyenne and an investor in the Union Pacific Railroad.

## Series
overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Series overview")]

### Season one
(2011–12)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Season one \(2011–12\)")]

Main article: [Hell on Wheels (season 1)](/wiki/Hell_on_Wheels_\(season_1\)
"Hell on Wheels \(season 1\)")

In 1865, former Confederate soldier Cullen Bohannon ([Anson
Mount](/wiki/Anson_Mount "Anson Mount")) journeys to the [Union Pacific
Railroad](/wiki/Union_Pacific_Railroad "Union Pacific Railroad")'s westward
construction of the First Transcontinental Railroad, seeking both work and
vengeance on the Union soldiers who killed his wife and son. Cullen gets hired
by the railroad and supervises an all-black "cut crew", including Elam
([Common](/wiki/Common_\(rapper\) "Common \(rapper\)")), whose job is to
prepare the terrain for track laying. Through conversation with the railroad
foreman, Daniel Johnson ([Ted Levine](/wiki/Ted_Levine "Ted Levine")), Cullen
learns more about his wife's death, but tragedy strikes before Johnson reveals
her killer's name. Thomas "Doc" Durant ([Colm Meaney](/wiki/Colm_Meaney "Colm
Meaney")) begins his "mad, noble quest" to expand his Union Pacific westward,
in order to complete the transcontinental railroad. Lily Bell ([Dominique
McElligott](/wiki/Dominique_McElligott "Dominique McElligott")) accompanies
her ailing husband, Robert ([Robert Moloney](/wiki/Robert_Moloney "Robert
Moloney")), as he surveys the landscape for the Union Pacific; when Robert is
killed by the Cheyenne natives, Lily must cope with being a widow on foreign
soil. Reverend Nathaniel Cole ([Tom Noonan](/wiki/Tom_Noonan "Tom Noonan"))
baptizes Joseph Black Moon ([Eddie Spears](/wiki/Eddie_Spears "Eddie
Spears")), a Cheyenne, then takes him under his tutelage in the church. Season
one ends with Bohannon killing a man he believes was responsible for the rape
and murder of his wife, only to discover that man was not there at the time.

### Season two
(2012)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Season two \(2012\)")]

Main article: [Hell on Wheels (season 2)](/wiki/Hell_on_Wheels_\(season_2\)
"Hell on Wheels \(season 2\)")

Bohannon tries to find himself again while continuing to drive the westward
expansion of the Union Pacific Railroad, under Durant's leadership. Bohannon
takes up with a gang of train robbers but is turned over to the Union Army and
imprisoned. Durant manages to get him pardoned. The railroad construction
enters the Sioux territory, where The Swede and a misguided Reverend Cole
assist the natives in attacking the railroad. Lily Bell seeks to gain control
of the railroad from Durant and mails his accounting ledgers to the
government. Army officers arrive to find the town has been attacked by the
Sioux.

### Season three
(2013)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Season three \(2013\)")]

Main article: [Hell on Wheels (season 3)](/wiki/Hell_on_Wheels_\(season_3\)
"Hell on Wheels \(season 3\)")

Bohannon abandons his quest to avenge his wife and son's deaths, in order to
battle Durant for control of the Union Pacific Railroad. Eva gives birth to a
baby who was sired during her marriage to Gregory Toole. Elam proposes
marriage to her, even though her post-partum depression weighs heavily on her.
The Swede takes up with a Mormon family on their way to the fictional Fort
Smith and later reveals his true nature.

### Season four
(2014)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Season four \(2014\)")]

Main article: [Hell on Wheels (season 4)](/wiki/Hell_on_Wheels_\(season_4\)
"Hell on Wheels \(season 4\)")

Conflict arises among the government and businesses, ranchers, homesteaders,
and the railroad, as all of those interests compete with one another for
control of [Cheyenne, Wyoming](/wiki/Cheyenne,_Wyoming "Cheyenne, Wyoming"),
the most important railroad hub in 1867. Meanwhile, the Union Pacific Railroad
continues its expansion westward, and Bohannon adjusts to being a husband and
father, again.

### Season five
(2015–16)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Season five \(2015–16\)")]

Main article: [Hell on Wheels (season 5)](/wiki/Hell_on_Wheels_\(season_5\)
"Hell on Wheels \(season 5\)")

In Season 5, set in California and [Laramie, Wyoming](/wiki/Laramie,_Wyoming
"Laramie, Wyoming"),[5] Bohannon is hired by the [Central Pacific
Railroad](/wiki/Central_Pacific_Railroad "Central Pacific Railroad") to build
the transcontinental railroad eastward over the [Sierra Nevada
Mountains](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)"). He
befriends its Chinese workers, including Mei, a woman disguised as a man known
as Fong. President [Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S.
Grant") increases the competition between the Central Pacific and Union
Pacific Railroad companies. This is further complicated by Thomas Durant's
corruption.

"Edit section: Production")]

### Development
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Development history")]

_Hell on Wheels_ was created by Joe and Tony Gayton in late 2008, and [Endemol
USA](/wiki/Endemol "Endemol")'s scripted television division, headed by senior
vice president of original programming Jeremy Gold, came on board to develop
the series for AMC.[6] On May 18, 2010, AMC placed a pilot order for _Hell on
Wheels_ with Endemol USA.[7] Joe and [Tony Gayton](/wiki/Tony_Gayton "Tony
Gayton") wrote the pilot, David Von Ancken was attached to the project as
director, and Jeremy Gold, Joe Gayton, and Tony Gayton served as executive
producers. On July 6, 2010, Endemol USA announced that they had entered into a
partnership with [Entertainment One](/wiki/Entertainment_One "Entertainment
One"), which would serve as the production studio on the project.[8]

Part of the deal between the two companies included provisions of
international distribution, with Endemol retaining rights to the series across
[Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), while Entertainment One acquired rights to
_Hell on Wheels_ in all remaining territories.[8] As a result of the deal,
Entertainment One also holds global rights for DVD and Blu-ray sales, as well
as video-on-demand and other digital distribution services.[8] The Canadian
production company Nomadic Pictures was brought onto the project to serve as
co-producers alongside Entertainment One.[9] The pilot was delivered to AMC
executives in November 2010.[9]

On November 12, 2010 it was reported by _[Deadline](/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood
"Deadline Hollywood")_ that the executives at AMC were impressed with the
pilot, and, coupled with the fact that the network had just cancelled their
drama series, _[Rubicon](/wiki/Rubicon_\(TV_series\) "Rubicon \(TV series\)")_
, were likely to order _Hell on Wheels_ to series.[9]

On December 15, 2010, AMC [green-lighted](/wiki/Green-light "Green-light") the
series with an order of 10 episodes.[10][11][12] Along with the series pickup,
AMC announced that Nomadic Pictures would again co-produce the series, as they
had done for the pilot, with Mike Frislev and Chad Oakes joining the series as
producers, while John Shiban and David Von Ancken joined the series as
executive producers; Von Ancken had previously served as director on the
pilot.[12][13] The network also announced that John Morayniss and Michael
Rosenberg would oversee production for Entertainment One, while Joel
Stillerman and Susie Fitzgerald would oversee production for AMC.[12][13]

On July 28, 2011, AMC announced that _Hell on Wheels_ would premiere on
November 6, 2011.[2] The series is produced by Entertainment One and Nomadic
Pictures.

On November 8, 2011, co-creator Joe Gayton spoke of the series' origins: "We
[Tony and I] started talking and remembered this story, _[American
Experience](/wiki/American_Experience "American Experience")_ , which was this
really great documentary, and I thought, 'God, that’s great. I just learned a
bunch of stuff I had never learned before.' You just have this cursory
information that the Chinese and the Irish built the railroad, but it got in
underneath all the dirt and stuff that went on, with the financing of it, and
the greed and corruption. And then, I heard about this Hell on Wheels place
and I went, 'What a great setting for a western.' So, we pitched that to
Jeremy Gold [at Endemol] and ended up taking it to AMC, and they loved it," he
said.[14]

On October 29, 2012, AMC renewed _Hell on Wheels_ for a third season,[15]
however it was also announced that the series creators and showrunners, Joe
and Tony Gayton, "will no longer be involved day-to-day on the show" and
series producer/writer/director [John Shiban](/wiki/John_Shiban "John Shiban")
would take over.[3] Following the departure of Shiban, the renewal was put on
hold until a replacement could be found.[16] On December 12, 2012, AMC
announced that [John Wirth](/wiki/John_Wirth_\(television_producer\) "John
Wirth \(television producer\)"), a writer for _[Terminator: The Sarah Connor
Chronicles](/wiki/Terminator:_The_Sarah_Connor_Chronicles "Terminator: The
Sarah Connor Chronicles")_ , will be the new showrunner, starting with the
show's third season.[17]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Casting")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/fb/Hell-On-
Wheels-350x192.jpg/220px-Hell-On-Wheels-350x192.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hell-On-
Wheels-350x192.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hell-On-Wheels-350x192.jpg "Enlarge")

Cullen Bohannon (Anson Mount) is the central character of the series.

Casting announcements began in July 2010, with
[Common](/wiki/Common_\(rapper\) "Common \(rapper\)") first to be cast. Common
portrays Elam Ferguson, "an emancipated slave who is working to achieve true
freedom in a world entrenched in prejudice".[2][18] Next to join the series
were [Anson Mount](/wiki/Anson_Mount "Anson Mount") and [Dominique
McElligott](/wiki/Dominique_McElligott "Dominique McElligott"), with Mount
playing Cullen Bohannon, "a former soldier hell bent on avenging his wife’s
death", and McElligott playing Lily Bell, "a newly widowed woman trying to
survive in a man’s world".[2][19] [Colm Meaney](/wiki/Colm_Meaney "Colm
Meaney") was next to be cast as Thomas "Doc" Durant, a "greedy entrepreneur
taking full advantage of the changing times".[2][20] [Ben
Esler](/wiki/Ben_Esler "Ben Esler"), [Phil Burke](/wiki/Phil_Burke "Phil
Burke") and [Eddie Spears](/wiki/Eddie_Spears "Eddie Spears") were the last
actors to be cast, with Esler playing Seán McGinnes and Burke playing Mickey
McGinnes, "two young brothers looking to find their fortune in the new West".
Spears was cast as Joseph Black Moon, "a Native American man torn between his
culture and the changing world around him".[2] It was later announced that
Jesse Lipscombe, Gerald Auger, [Robert Moloney](/wiki/Robert_Moloney "Robert
Moloney") and [Ted Levine](/wiki/Ted_Levine "Ted Levine") had joined the
series as recurring guest stars.[21][22]

[Jennifer Ferrin](/wiki/Jennifer_Ferrin "Jennifer Ferrin") joined the cast as
a series regular for season three, playing a _[New York
Sun](/wiki/The_New_York_Sun "The New York Sun")_ journalist covering the
construction of the railroad.[23] AMC announced that [Dohn
Norwood](/wiki/Dohn_Norwood "Dohn Norwood") (Psalms) became a series regular
for season three.[24]

[Jake Weber](/wiki/Jake_Weber "Jake Weber") joined the fourth season's cast.
He was initially to portray a [carpetbagger](/wiki/Carpetbagger
"Carpetbagger") seeking to profit from the frontier,[25] but his role changed
to [John Allen Campbell](/wiki/John_Allen_Campbell "John Allen Campbell"),
first governor of Wyoming. [MacKenzie Porter](/wiki/MacKenzie_Porter
"MacKenzie Porter") has also been cast. She will replace [Siobhan
Williams](/wiki/Siobhan_Williams "Siobhan Williams") in the role of Naomi,
Bohannon's Mormon bride.[26]

#### Cast
quotes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Cast quotes")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Anson_Mount_-
_Cannes.jpg/220px-Anson_Mount_-_Cannes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Anson_Mount_-
_Cannes.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Anson_Mount_-_Cannes.jpg "Enlarge")

"There’s a lot of just being in the right place at the right time, as well as
being in the right place and time in my life. I couldn’t have played this role
10 years ago—I needed a little bit of life behind me. I’d been wanting to do a
western for years but never had the opportunity to do that. So I immediately
responded to this project, and I especially responded to the fact that the
lead was a southern character who’s not stereotyped and not villainized."[27]
— [Anson Mount](/wiki/Anson_Mount "Anson Mount")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Colm_Meaney_-
_Seminci_2011.jpg/220px-Colm_Meaney_-
_Seminci_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Colm_Meaney_-_Seminci_2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Colm_Meaney_-_Seminci_2011.jpg "Enlarge")

"I usually read a script from an audience perspective first, and then look
more closely at the character. With this, it was a complete page-turner. It
was fantastically entertaining. And then, specifically looking at the
character that they wanted me to play, it really got my juices going. You
don’t see writing like this, nowadays. The vocabulary he uses is just
fantastic. There was no hesitation."[28] — [Colm Meaney](/wiki/Colm_Meaney
"Colm Meaney")

[Common](/wiki/Common_\(rapper\) "Common \(rapper\)") spoke about the
challenges of playing a former [slave](/wiki/Slave "Slave"): "Very
challenging. And that's why I took it on. It's a lot of responsibility because
what black people went through in slavery, within that system of slavery, was
really treacherous. And for me, I felt like I owed it to the people that lived
during that time to bring something truthful to the character. And even just
revisiting some of the experiences of it, [there] was just a lot of emotion
and a lot of pain. At the same time, a lot of strength came from it. What I
enjoy most about the character is the fact that he was written so strong, not
as just a person that was oppressed and kept his head down."[29]

Canadian actor [Christopher Heyerdahl](/wiki/Christopher_Heyerdahl
"Christopher Heyerdahl") talks about how he got his role and the rarity of a
Scandinavian character: "Well, luck and providence, I suppose. They say,
'What’s luck? Preparation and opportunity.' So, I guess the opportunity came,
in the form of an audition. I put myself on tape, and they responded to it. I
went in and did a call-back audition, and they felt that we were on the same
track. My idea of who The Swede was, was the same as theirs, and vice versa.
This kind of character is very rare, with the fact that it fit so well with my
background and my understanding of a Norwegian man. It all just fell into
place. I still get a little choked up thinking about how often a character
like this comes along. For the viewer, it’s quite interesting. It’s not a
character that we see very often, and certainly not in this form. As an actor,
it seemed to be tailor-made for me. It’s quite wonderful."[30]

Irish actress [Dominique McElligott](/wiki/Dominique_McElligott "Dominique
McElligott") never expected to be cast in a period American role: "I was
hanging out in London, having drinks with friends who are all flight
attendants, and they said that they would get me over to America for free, and
I could stay and do some meetings and auditions. _Hell on Wheels_ was the
first one. I arrived on the 5th of July, and the _Hell on Wheels_ audition was
on the 6th or the 7th. It was crazy! They didn’t know me, at all. Obviously, I
loved the pilot and I loved the character, but I didn’t anticipate ever
actually getting the chance to do it. When you go up for these brilliant
parts, you just figure, 'Okay, well, they’re going to pick some American
actress, and that will be that.' But, the opportunity was there, and I really
enjoyed the audition. It was fun."[31]

### Exterior
filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Exterior filming")]

Filming of the first season took place in [Calgary](/wiki/Calgary "Calgary"),
as well as areas in central and southern [Alberta](/wiki/Alberta "Alberta"),
Canada.[32] The [T'suu T'ina Native Indian
Reservation](/wiki/Tsuu_T%27ina_Nation_145,_Alberta "Tsuu T'ina Nation 145,
Alberta"), an [Indian reserve](/wiki/Indian_reserve "Indian reserve") in
southern Alberta, was the location for most of the exteriors.[33]

Exterior filming of the second season was near the [Bow River](/wiki/Bow_River
"Bow River") in Calgary. Interior filming was in a building near the city's
airport. Series producers expected the filming of the season's ten episodes to
take about 80 days.[1]

Filming of the third season was suspended part way through the sixth episode
when the location was included in the mandatory evacuation area due to the
[flooding in southern Alberta](/wiki/2013_Alberta_floods "2013 Alberta
floods").[34] Originally, producers had announced a two-day shut down, when
the only road to the location was underwater.[35] Later, on June 21, producers
announced that the production hiatus, scheduled to begin June 27, would take
effect immediately.[34] Anson Mount shared pictures of the nearby river and
exterior sets flooding on June 20 and 21.[34][36][37]

Filming of the fourth season's 13 episodes took place along the Bow River.
Filming occurred from April 24 to September 24, 2014.[38]

The fifth season's production filming occurred on the CL Ranch, west of
Calgary, for the [Truckee, California](/wiki/Truckee,_California "Truckee,
California"), and [Laramie, Wyoming](/wiki/Laramie,_Wyoming "Laramie,
Wyoming"), locations. The [Kananaskis Country](/wiki/Kananaskis_Country
"Kananaskis Country") park system, 40 miles west of the ranch, served as the
[Sierra Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)")
mountains the Central Pacific must cross.[39]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Critical response")]

The first season was given 63% on [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic")
based on 28 reviews, indicating a "generally favorable" impression.[40] The
second season was given 60% on Metacritic, indicating "mixed or average"
reviews.[41] The _[Washington Post](/wiki/Washington_Post "Washington Post")_
's Hank Stuever rated the show highly, commenting, "Hands down, the most
intriguing show on the fall slate. Though imbued with epic sweep, _Hell on
Wheels_ is a western at heart, even if that heart is cold. Plenty of guns,
knives, arrows, scalpings – mixed with the incendiary socio-psychological
wounds left in the Civil War’s wake."[42]

Robert Lloyd of the _[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles
Times")_ says the show "...takes its cues more from the movies than from life.
Never, in the episodes I watched, did I feel as if I were actually seeing how
a railroad got built, and sometimes it took a bit of squinting not to see the
characters as actors in a field, reading lines. Still, for all the unlikely
things [the creators] make happen in order to get their characters into place,
and the dogged refusal of a couple of those characters to become interesting
at all, the show gathers steam as it goes on."[43]

The _[Wall Street Journal](/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal "Wall Street Journal")_
's Nancy Dewolf Smith comments: " 'Hell on Wheels' finds enough beauty, danger
and emotion to make some part of every episode seem fresh and worth waiting
for. Not that new is always a good thing. Despite striking performances even
in many of the smaller roles, the actors sometimes are made to symbolize very
modern obsessions, e.g. with race and gender. The sight of modern
sensibilities lurking behind the curtains can break ye olde spell."[44]

Brian Lowry of _[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_
writes: "While the diverse mix of characters could work to the program's
advantage over the long haul, jumping to and fro among them creates a diluted,
herky-jerky ride in the early going."[45]

The _[Washington Post](/wiki/Washington_Post "Washington Post")_ reported that
the series has been criticized for not depicting [Chinese
immigrants](/wiki/Chinese_American#Influence_on_American_culture "Chinese
American") during the transcontinental railroad construction scenes. Creator
Joe Gayton said "budget-wise and time-wise . . . we could really only
concentrate on one side of [the railroad building], and that’s probably why
we, you know, that's why we chose the [emanating from the East Coast] Union
Pacific as opposed to the [emanating from the West Coast] Central
Pacific."[46] By the fifth season, the show expanded its focus to include a
significant look at the role of Chinese immigrant workers in the growth of the
railroad.

###
Ratings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Ratings")]

The pilot, premiering November 6. 2011, was watched by 4.4 million viewers –
AMC's second-highest series premiere in history, following _[The Walking
Dead](/wiki/The_Walking_Dead_\(TV_series\) "The Walking Dead \(TV series\)")_.
Among key demographics, the pilot episode was viewed by 2.4 million viewers in
the adults 18–49 category, and 2.3 million viewers in the adults 25–54
demographics, according to Nielsen. The total viewership bested network slot
rivals _[CSI: Miami](/wiki/CSI:_Miami "CSI: Miami")_ and _[Pan
Am](/wiki/Pan_Am_\(TV_series\) "Pan Am \(TV series\)")_.[47] The sixth episode
was watched by 2.15 million viewers, the lowest viewership of the first season
and had a 0.6 rating in the 18–49 age range.[48] The viewership numbers
eventually rebounded with the season one finale being watched by 2.84 million
viewers, maintaining its steady 0.7 rating in the 18–49 age range.[49] In
January 2012, following the season one finale, AMC confirmed _Hell on Wheels_
as the network's second-highest rated original series, behind _The Walking
Dead_ , averaging three million viewers per episode.[50]

## International
distribution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: International distribution")]

The series is shown in Australia on [FX Australia](/wiki/FX_Australia "FX
Australia")[75] and in Ireland on [RTÉ](/wiki/RT%C3%89 "RTÉ").[76]

## Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hell_on_Wheels_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Home media")]

All five seasons of _Hell on Wheels_ have been released in [DVD](/wiki/DVD
"DVD") and [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray") formats.[77][78][79][80][81][82]
The complete series was also released in DVD and Blu-ray formats on November
1, 2016, comprising 17 discs.[83] As of August 2018, it was available in the
United States on [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix")'s online streaming
service.
